https://www.fra.dot.gov/eLib/details/L01494#p1_z5_gD_lEA

Description: Doe Run Resources Corp. of St. Louis, North America's largest lead producer, agreed to spend approximately $65 million to correct violations of several environmental laws at 10 of its lead mining, milling and smelting facilities in southeast Missouri, the Justice Department, Environmental Protection Agency and the Missouri Department of Natural Resources announced. As part of the settlement, Doe Run will pay a civil penalty of $7 million for violating a series of environmental laws, including the federal Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act, Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, Emergency Planning and Right-to-Know Act, Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act (known as Superfund), and the Missouri Air Conservation Law, Clean Water Law and Hazardous Waste Management Law.
Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
Info Source: http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/north-america-s-largest-lead-producer-spend-65-million-correct-environmental-violations
https://www.fmcsa.dot.gov/regulations/enforcement/national-listing-enforcement-cases-subject-name-closed-fiscal-year-2007-pdf
Notes: Year is fiscal year. Date is closing date.

Description: The Wage and Hour Division found Inteva Products LLC violated Fair Labor Standards Act provisions when it failed to include workers' shift differentials when calculating overtime rates for hourly employees at one facility in Michigan and two in Alabama. The employer based overtime payment on the employees' base hourly rates, rather than paying time and one-half of their total earnings per hour, as the law requires.
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: https://www.dol.gov/newsroom/releases/whd/whd20161214-0
https://www.fra.dot.gov/eLib/details/L04190#p1_z5_gD_lEA

Private Litigation Case Title: Aubuchan et al v. Doe Run Resources Corporation et al

Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20150910050205/http://ago.mo.gov/home/news-archives/2012-news-archives/ag-koster-reaches-settlement-with-doe-run-for-the-sweetwater-mine-and-mill

Description: Doe Run agreed to pay approximately $65 million in cleanup and a $7 million civil penalty in settlement of allegations it violated several environmental laws at its lead mining, milling and smelting facilities in Missouri. Half the civil penalty went to the federal government. The settlement was also announced by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/mo-doe-run-resources-corp
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20150910050206/http://ago.mo.gov/home/news-archives/2010-news-archives/ag-koster-announces-72-million-settlement-with-doe-run

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
NAICS Translation: 336111: Automobile Manufacturing
Info Source: February 7, 2020 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Agency: Environmental Protection Agency referral to the Justice Department
